Entries.default: An eyebrow the blue of the open sea rises over an iris the warm green of the shallow surf.
"You be boring a hole in me with them eyes, cap. I'd offer an ouble for your thoughts, but I prefer not to make deals I ain't got no intention to keep."
"I could say the same of you. You doing okay?"
"I know things could have gone better back on Sayuka, but they could have gone worse, too."
"You wanted to talk? Talk."
"I don't have time for this nonsense right now."
"I be fine, actually. Strange though it be."
"Fine, cap. Don't be sparing me no thoughts."

"Aye. We could've gone and done something we couldn't be taking back."

He rubs the bridge of his nose.
"Could they've, cap? A good man lies dead. A man who mattered to me more than, well, more than most anything. And to what end?"
"You be a strange fish, cap. Sometimes you ain't half bad. Other times you be a right poxy cog-sucker."

"I suppose it would keel haul you twice over to be acting half decent for a change."

Scowling, he rolls his eyes.

"Aye."

With a meager shrug he turns away.
"If you want to talk, I'll listen."

"Not sure there be much to say, captain."

He looks away.
"Then let's shove off."
"You found out you were inadvertently aiding the trade of slaves. That couldn't have felt good."
"There are rules, Serafen. Remaro knew them. He broke them anyway."
"Remaro's not gone, Serafen. He's merely rejoined the wheel. He'll move on and be born again."
"The gods set trials before us, Serafen, some far more difficult than others, but none impossible. For good or ill, we have their particular interest."
"Best you face it. Remaro died because he was a traitor. A traitor to you, and to your people."
"I'm deeply sorry that you had to experience that. If there's anything I can do, you need only tell me."
"At least you've got someone to stay with if you ever travel out west. Had that myself, until someone broke my castle."
"Shut your ballast hole already. Everyone's got shit to deal with. Yours isn't worse than anybody else's."
"It's not ideal, and it won't make everyone happy, but this resolution is what'll make the most people happy."
"We need to tell the Consuaglo about Bastian's slaving. To set the record straight."
"Remaro did the right thing, you know. Those slaver bastards deserved what they got!"
"Remaro did the wrong thing, whatever his reasons. You can be better than that. You can make the Príncipi better."
"Don't suppose we could collect on the Príncipi's bounty anyway?"
"Sayuka was a tough break. Only thing to do is to pick yourself up and keep moving."

"Aye, cap. Didn't feel at all good. Right brilliant you are."

He winces.
"Gods, I know, cap. Remaro saw to it my learning of the laws of the sea were damn near cyclopedic. Just wish I understood why - after all that - he went and broke them."

"Guess we'd better be seeing to your big blue friend then, aye?"

Hands resting on his weapons, Serafen turns away.

"All who tread the sea possess some faith, cap. Some of us be having a little less than others."

He shrugs.

"You ain't even with us!"

He throws his hands up.

"Things ain't usually as black and white as you be suggesting, but I'll be keeping your understanding of the world in mind, Captain Watcher."

He turns from you.

"I... be appreciating the sentiment, I suppose."

He rubs the back of his head and looks away.

"Ha! That be a point and a half. Mayhaps I'll go find meself Remaro one of these days. After we've done dealt with everything here."

With a grin and a soft chuckle, he turns away.

"Heh, aye. Too bad I be having no interest in seeing the old salt again."

He sighs and turns from you.
The orlan's lime green eyes blink as if you'd slapped him, then narrow.

"Aye. Suppose we take our victories where we be finding them."

He sighs and turns away.

"Despite it all, cap, I be right glad to be serving with you."

He bows and turns away.

"Might could. Without a head, though, that'll be a right hard con."

He chuckles softly.

"It be the shit like this that turns us old salts hard."

He stretches and turns away.

"It be the shit like this that turns us old salts hard."

He stretches and turns away.
The orlan's lime green eyes blink as if you'd slapped him, then narrow.

"Guess I'll be charting those waters meself. With your help, of course."

He grins, salutes, and turns away.
"Or mayhaps we did just that."

"Sorry bout that. Weren't fair to you."

He scuffs a boot against the ground.
He looks to you, holding your gaze with his. He snorts quietly, nodding.

"This conversation be well and truly over."

He turns from you.

"This conversation be well and truly over."

He turns from you.

"Aye, cap. Much as I hate an honest word, some truths ain't for burial at sea."

He smiles.

"That and more beside. I'm sure Remaro made it quick and painless, the soft old salt."

He smiles.

"Mayhaps. But be our rules too loose or too strict? Who's got the right of it, and who do we hoist our sails behind?"

He sighs and rubs his temple.
Nodding, the orlan expels a long, slow sigh.
